name: X vs Y Comparison Post
description: Compelling comparison post that contrasts two approaches, strategies, or mindsets while revealing deeper insights about what actually drives success. Takes a clear stance.
use_when: Contrasting two approaches to solving the same problem
Challenging conventional wisdom with a better method
Sharing mindset shifts (beginner vs expert, old way vs new way)
Teaching through comparison rather than direct instruction
Making a slightly contrarian argument backed by experience

patterns: I've tried both [X] and [Y]. Here's what works:
Everyone's obsessed with [X]. But [Y] is what actually matters.

context.purpose: Why this comparison matters to the reader
context.requirement: Brief setup that makes stakes clear

x_approach.structure: X people focus on [behavior]. They [specific example of what this looks like].

y_approach.structure: Y people do the opposite. They [contrasting behavior] because [reasoning].
y_approach.requirement: Show clear contrast with X approach

personal_story.purpose: Illustrate the difference with real example
patterns: A client recently told me [specific story]...

key_insight.purpose: Explain the deeper 'why' behind which approach works
patterns: What most people miss is [key understanding]
The problem with X is [limitation]. Y works because [advantage]
key_insight.requirement: Take a clear stance - don't say 'both have merit'

what_it_requires.purpose: Be honest about what the better approach demands

practical_takeaway.purpose: Broader implication or specific next action
practical_takeaway.example: Start by [specific first step] this week.

examples: Have you made this shift yet?

comparison_patterns.mindset_comparison: Beginners vs Experts | Amateurs vs Pros | Old me vs New me
comparison_patterns.strategy_comparison: Most people vs Top 1% | Traditional vs Modern | Safe vs Bold
comparison_patterns.tactical_comparison: Old way vs New way | Complicated vs Simple | Theory vs Practice

quality_criteria.description: X and Y approaches are clearly distinct and specific
Takes clear position on which approach is better (no fence-sitting)
Uses concrete examples, not abstract concepts
Includes real story or observation, not hypothetical
Explains WHY one approach works better, not just WHAT

tone_requirements.opinionated: Take a clear stance, don't be wishy-washy
tone_requirements.conversational: Like explaining to a friend over coffee
tone_requirements.contrarian: Challenge conventional wisdom (but back it up)

forbidden_patterns: Don't write bullet-pointed lists - use natural paragraphs
Don't use template language with [brackets] in output
Don't give balanced 'both have merit' take - pick a side
Don't use generic comparisons - need specific examples
Don't skip the personal story - it sells the insight
examples:
Most founders focus on growth. Smart ones focus on retention.

Growth people obsess over acquisition cost, ad spend, viral loops. They celebrate hitting 10K users while ignoring that 80% churned in month one.

Retention people do the opposite. They study why the 20% stayed, then double down on that. Because they know: 100 users who stick around beat 10,000 who bounce.

I learned this after burning $50K on ads that brought 5,000 signups. 94% churned. Felt like a genius until I looked at retention.

The real difference? Growth is a vanity metric until retention proves you built something people actually want.

What's your experience been?
agent_instructions: Agent should identify X and Y from context (brand positioning, company docs, user topic). DO NOT ask user to fill in X/Y template - infer the comparison from the request. Use brand voice for tone. Pull personal stories from conversation_history or company_documents if available. Take a clear stance based on brand values.
